Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: From Communication to Power Networks: Adaptive Energy Management for Power Systems with Renewables

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Pressing environmental issues, security of energy supply sites, as well as their reliability in case of grid outages, drive research and development efforts toward renewable energy sources (RES) worldwide. RES however are volatile and intermittent, exhibit large fluctuations, and are certainly uncertain. Accounting for the uncertainty of RES is key to efficient management of distributed energy resources (DER), which include electricity generators, energy storage units (batteries) and programmable loads (such as smart appliances). These are the basic entities of a microgrid comprising a localized collection of DER that can operate in either grid-connected or islanded modes. Attractive features of microgrids include the ability to integrate constantly growing amounts of green energy, and highly reliable autonomous operation even in case of grid outages, e.g., under natural disasters. The overarching theme of this project is reliable and economic microgrid energy management that accounts for the uncertainty and volatility of high-penetration renewables.

In particular, this research addresses the major microgrid energy management challenges through development of (i) robust and risk-constrained methodologies, which adapt to the uncertain RES; and (ii) tractable, scalable, and decentralized control and coordination of DER units. One of the main features of this project?s research is scheduling of controllable DER, such as fuel-based generators, batteries, and smart appliances, in a way that guarantees system-wide efficiency objectives even in the face of unpredictable RES generation. Emphasis is also placed on development of scalable algorithms, whose complexity increases gracefully with the proliferation of generation and storage units as well as and controllable loads in microgrids, and modern distribution systems, in general. In a nutshell, this project contributes to significantly upgrading the analysis and design of microgrid operations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Inspired by resource allocation advances in telecommunication networks over wireless fading channels, the objective of this project was to develop innovative approaches to microgrid energy management that account for the uncertainty and volatility of high-penetration renewable energy sources. Emphasis was placed on: (i) robust and risk-constrained methodologies, which adapt to the uncertain renewable energy sources; and (ii) tractable, scalable, and decentralized control and coordination of distributed energy resource units. The identified research themes were motivated by the urgent need to integrate constantly growing amounts of green energy into modern power systems, and bring them closer to the distribution level and electricity end-users. The ultimate goal was to provide a host of energy management methodologies for microgrids with widely deployed renewables, and markedly upgrade the analysis and design of microgrid operations.

Outcomes with major intellectual merits included: a) Real-time load elasticity tracking and pricing for electric vehicle charging; b) distributed stochastic market clearing with high-penetration wind power and large-scale demand response; c) maximizing sum-rate for MIMO downlink systems powerd by renewables; d) stochastic control for multipoint communication systems with renewables; e) scalable scheduling of electric vehicles via battery swapping; and f) power system state estimation via feasible point pursuit.

As far as broader impact, novel approaches and computational tools were developed for analysis and design of large-scale complex networks operating under uncertainty, that could further benefit social and other infrastructure (e.g., transportation) networks. The algorithms and insights developed for resource management in microgrids can also permeate benefits to a gamut of domains, including logistics, communication networks, and operations research. At an even higher level, the developed tools will positively impact the environment and societal embracing of the novel power grid technologies. Broader transformative impact was effected through training of 3 PhD and 3 MSc students (3 joined academia and 3 pursued their careers in industry focusing on energy analytics). Last but not least, a senior design team of undergraduates completed a software toolboox for "Monitoring the U. of Minnesota’s Energy Consumption.”
